These dialogues provide an opportunity for community discourse and reflection on biological, social, and cultural categories—including class, gender, sexual orientation, race, religion, and other identities—and their impact on and within healthcare and the practice of medicine.   We offer these dialogues throughout the year.  Visit our calendar to see the next scheduled Intersections Dialogue session, or contact Chelsea Fullerton at Chelsea.Fullerton@nyumc.org for more information.                                                                                        NYU Langone Medical Center       Student Login       Library                 Policies & Disclaimers

Issue 1. Winter/Spring Spotlight on Education Gender & Health Selective Piloted with 3-Year Pathway Students   Building on Momentum: Second Cohort Finish Health Disparities Concentration     Spotlight on Pipeline/Pre-Professional Programs   Spotlight on Research   Alumni Corner: Nicole Hindman, MD   Special Topics: Intersections of Race, Culture, and Social Identities in Medicine       Student Awards     LGBTQ Resources       open/close   Medical Education  About the Office of Medical Education   MD Curriculum   Clinical Training Sites       open/close   Student Health  About Us   Clinical Services   Mental Health Services   Emergencies   Immunization Info   New Student Info   Visiting Student Resources   Wellness Information   Additional Info   Confidentiality   Staff/Contact Info   Additonal Forms                                                                        Gender & Health Selective Piloted with 3-Year Pathway Students                                                July 2013 marked the inaugural offering of the Gender & Health Selective , an innovative new course piloted by the Office of Diversity Affairs with six 3-year pathway medical students.  The selective focused on gender, sex, and sexuality as biomedical and psychosocial determinants of health, and explored specific health disparities as functions of these categories.  This initial session included over 30 hours of didactics on a diverse range of topics, including issues specific to men’s health, women’s health, and lesbian, gay, bisexual, & transgender (LGBT) health.  Students also engaged in a variety of clinical site experiences where they translated classroom principles into concrete practice.     Brian Sanders, a student in his first year of the 3-year pathway, said, “My experiences as part of the Gender & Health course expanded my understanding of the discrepancies involved in healthcare and in the scientific literature, the many opportunities available to be of assistance, and an awareness of some of the variables involved in the presentation and treatment of illness between patients of different gender and race.”   The initial Gender & Health course inspired students to explore these issues further throughout the duration of their medical training.  Sanders explained, “I have gained an appreciation of the many economic and social factors that impede members of specific communities from receiving equal healthcare opportunities and have been encouraged and trained to join the fight to remove these obstacles.”   The students participated in a simulated exercise that was ranked highly during the course’s evaluation. Hosted in the NYSIM Center for all eighteen 3-year pathway students, the simulation required students to practice taking a sexual history with three standardized patients portrayed by trained actors.  The cases focused on health disparities across race and gender. One case specifically focused on sexual history taking with a transgender patient, which provided students who had not encountered transgender patients previously an opportunity to gain cultural competency in providing health care for a particular subset of the LGBT population.  This activity was recently described on the Association of American Medical Colleges’ Wing of Zock blog.  All 3-year pathway students rated this activity as their favorite in their medical training thus far.    Overall, the Gender & Health Selective has been met with immense success and appreciation from the student body.  First-year medical student Jenna Tarasoff explained, “I emerged from this course with a greater understanding of the unique ways in which one's sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, and race can affect disease, access to care, and health-related decisions. The combination of lectures, class reflections, narrative medicine discussions, journal club, and clinical shadowing provided for an incredibly rich and diverse learning experience!"  We are in the process of expanding this course to include MS3 and MS4 students, and are excited to offer the next session in summer of 2014. Professional Pathways | NYU School of Law                          Skip to main content                                     ›               Quicklinks       Areas of Study   Calendar   Career Services   Colloquia   Courses   Departments   Directories   Docket   Housing   Library   News and Press   NYU Home   Student Links   Technology                                              JD Admissions   Faculty & Scholarship   Global Opportunities   LLM/JSD Admissions   Academics & Courses   Law & Business   Executive Education   Current Students   Public Service   About NYU Law   Alumni & Giving   Centers & Institutes                               Home › Academics › Professional Pathways             Professional Pathways                 Academics       Areas of Study   Professional Pathways   Interdisciplinary   Courses   Degrees Offered   Lawyering Program   Clinics   Colloquia   Legal Ethics   Exams   Fellowships   Law Teaching Programs   Conferences and Symposia                           Faculty-designed Professional Pathways guide students in a focused area of study and skill development in particular areas of law, the bulk of which they will pursue during their 3L year. Pathways are designed to help students who have developed interest in a particular career area and make them highly competitive in the job market for that field. Professional Pathways offer curricular advice on how to best prepare for a career in the following areas:     Civil Litigation   Criminal Practice   Global Legal Practice   Intellectual Property and Information Law   Law and Business   Tax     Of course, these are just a few of the practice areas open to our students. We support students who are interested pursuing all kinds of employment after law school, including judicial clerkships and careers in law or accounting firms, corporations, public interest organizations, government or academia .
